articles.headline: Southern Baptists Vote to Oppose Use of I.V.F.
articles.snippet: With almost 13 million church members across the United States, the Southern Baptist Convention has long been a bellwether for American evangelicalism.
articles.abstract: With almost 13 million church members across the United States, the Southern Baptist Convention has long been a bellwether for American evangelicalism.
articles.lead_paragraph: Southern Baptists, the country’s largest Protestant denomination, voted on Wednesday to oppose the use of in vitro fertilization. The vote was an indication that evangelicals are increasingly open to arguments that equate embryos with human life, and that two years after the overturning of Roe v. Wade, “fetal personhood” may be the next front for the anti-abortion movement.

articles.headline: China Is Testing More Driverless Cars Than Any Other Country
articles.snippet: Assisted driving systems and robot taxis are becoming more popular with government help, as cities designate large areas for testing on public roads.
articles.abstract: Assisted driving systems and robot taxis are becoming more popular with government help, as cities designate large areas for testing on public roads.
articles.lead_paragraph: The world’s largest experiment in driverless cars is underway on the busy streets of Wuhan, a city in central China with 11 million people, 4.5 million cars, eight-lane expressways and towering bridges over the muddy waters of the Yangtze River.

articles.headline: Tesla Share Price Is Its Own Referendum on Musk
articles.snippet: A huge run-up in the stock’s value followed a 2018 vote on Elon Musk’s compensation package. But investors have recently become less enamored.
articles.abstract: A huge run-up in the stock’s value followed a 2018 vote on Elon Musk’s compensation package. But investors have recently become less enamored.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Tesla shareholder vote over Elon Musk’s pay is in some ways a referendum on the performance of the company and its chief executive.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Angry Catholics Wanted to Burn the Church. He Came to Save It.
articles.snippet: In a cold, remote corner of northern Quebec, a sexual abuse scandal pushed a church to the edge. The Rev. Gérard Tsatselam, from Cameroon, must comfort the afflicted to bring it back.
articles.abstract: In a cold, remote corner of northern Quebec, a sexual abuse scandal pushed a church to the edge. The Rev. Gérard Tsatselam, from Cameroon, must comfort the afflicted to bring it back.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Rev. Gérard Tsatselam boarded the ferryboat and settled in his usual place, on a reclining seat, at the back of a cold, unlit room that would have been packed in summer. Uneasy, he sat shrouded in his large, black coat as high winter winds delayed the boat’s arrival in the village where he was trying to save the church.
articles.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Renaud Philippe

articles.headline: HBO Could Use a Hit. Enter the Dragons.
articles.snippet: The network has hit an unusually fallow period. Executives hope “House of the Dragon,” which returns Sunday, could be the start of a new winning streak.
articles.abstract: The network has hit an unusually fallow period. Executives hope “House of the Dragon,” which returns Sunday, could be the start of a new winning streak.
articles.lead_paragraph: The dragons are back. And not a moment too soon.

articles.headline: Supreme Court, in Starbucks Ruling, Curbs Labor Regulator’s Authority
articles.snippet: In a blow to the National Labor Relations Board, the justices made it more difficult to order employers to reinstate fired workers.
articles.abstract: In a blow to the National Labor Relations Board, the justices made it more difficult to order employers to reinstate fired workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of Starbucks on Thursday in a challenge against a labor ruling by a federal judge, making it more difficult for a key federal agency to intervene when a company is accused of illegally suppressing labor organizing.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Santul Nerkar
